utterances: Steve Seche, the career diplomat, was U.S.

Death to America.

government still has an ally in Yemen.

I can tell you that some of our counterterrorism partnership efforts continue in Yemen, that there are national security relationships that continue to exist and continue to be useful in protecting the United States.
But, you know, we obviously are concerned about the situation in Yemen, about the political instability.
And you can add Yemen to a long list that includes Syria, Iraq and Libya, among others, as concerns for President Obama.
Tamara Keith, NPR News, the White House.
And one additional note on the topic of Yemen.

still has a partner in Yemen.

Statisticians resigned in protest, including PC Mohanan.
He helped calculate the unemployment rate at that record high of 6.1%.
Traditionally, we have been clocking an unemployment rate of just over 3% all along.
So that is why suddenly 6% becomes a big number for us.
And Mohanan says it could actually be higher because the majority of Indians, despite their aspirations, are still stuck doing menial labor.
More than half work in agriculture, and they are difficult to count.
It's not like they get pay stubs, Mohanan says.
So it's not that easy to measure employment like the way you do it in the U.S.
and other countries.

If they had a better option, they wouldn't be doing that.

From NPR News, it's Day to Day.
The Illinois Attorney General today asked the state Supreme Court to declare Governor Rod Blagojevich unable to serve.
That's following federal corruption charges brought against him.
People are now paying closer attention to Illinois Lieutenant Governor Pat Quinn, who could take over for Blagojevich.
Chicago public radio's Ben Calhoun brings us this profile.
Before becoming Lieutenant Governor, Pat Quinn spent years as a consumer rights advocate.
During that time he was famous for holding press conferences on Sundays because there wasn't much news and it was easier for him to get attention.
Of course, with the current turmoil in Illinois, Quinn doesn't have to work nearly that hard to get media face time.
Good morning to you.
Good morning, Meredith.
This is Quinn earlier this week doing an interview with the Today Show.
I really think that the governor needs to resign and step aside right now, and I think that will happen.
For Pat Quinn, it's been a sudden and big change.
He's been around government for a long time.
He worked for former Chicago Mayor Herald Washington and even served a term as state treasurer in the '90s, but in a state where insider politics rules he's always been an outsider.
Take, for example, one of the first things he did as a public figure.
In 1980, he led a grassroots campaign to reduce the number of state representatives in Illinois.
Though voters passed it overwhelmingly, Quinn's efforts didn't earn him too many friends among Illinois politicians.
The Lieutenant Governor has that kind of image today.
Critics call him a show horse, or worse a gadfly.
His fans see him as a do-gooder populist, who does what's necessary to further his cause.
Pat suggested that we walk across the state.
Dr.
Quintin Young is one of the state's top health care advocates.
He's known Pat Quinn for decades as his friend and as his doctor.
In August 200, the two men walked across the entire state in the name of health-care reform.
Young says his most prominent memory is that Quinn would end everyday the same way.
He'd make you a line in the adjacent lawn and when we'd start the next day he absolutely insisted that we start from that point.
Young says Quinn's so squeaky clean sometimes it makes him laugh.
Young says reading about profanity-laced recordings of Blagojevich this week has often made him think of Quinn.
You know, in normal conversation when would you say damn, he would encourage you not to use bad language.
I like that.
Now, even though they've run on the same ticket twice, Quinn and Blagojevich are not close.
In Illinois, the lieutenant governor and the governor run in separate races in the primary and then get melded into one ticket for the general election.
During the 2006 election, the public saw them as so different that some people had bumper stickers reading, Blago indicted '06, Quinn governor '07.
He is the antithesis of Rod Blagojevich.
Cindy Canary runs the Illinois Campaign for Political Reform, one of the state's top watch-dog groups.
She says Quinn's a reformer who would be a breath of fresh air.
Canary also finds it remarkable that the alleged insider deals and old school corruption that appear likely to bring down Blagojevich could put an outsider like Pat Quinn into power.
If not for this circumstance, could you see him becoming governor?
Without these extraordinary, extraordinary circumstances I don't think that Pat Quinn would be looking at being governor.
He might imagine it, but I don't think it would happen.

Johnson is planning to travel to Detroit, San Antonio, Texas, and other cities, over the next few months, on a listening tour for outreach.
The group is also trying to recruit more younger members, specifically those between the ages of 21 and 35.
That's a demographic that's been largely missing within the organization, according to the local president of the NAACP's Washington, D.C., branch, Akosua Ali.
Young people do not know everything.
But they have the energy.
They have the will.
They have the tenacity.
Paired with the knowledge of our elders, we can be an immovable force.
Ali's 34 and first joined the NAACP through a college chapter, where she and other students were trained as activists.
The NAACP specifically has the base of youth that are already trained.
So it's even more important for us to be able to build upon that foundation and keep them connected so that they don't transition out.
